references: This paper provides a comprehensive review of FL and TL techniques for CD based on medical image analysis. This paper is compared to existing survey articles along several key dimensions in Table 1. The survey provides the most comprehensive coverage across FL, TL, model analysis, applications, and future outlook. Multiple cancer domains are spanned and the two techniques are examined. Other reviews usually only look at FL or TL separately. This review looks at how both methods work together to improve CD from medical images. A complete overview is provided of the roles and combined benefits of FL and TL. This makes this review unique and useful for researchers and healthcare professionals working in this field.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Key differences between FL and TL for CD
S4.T2.table:
Key Differences Federated Learning Transfer Learning
Technique Decentralized ML approach that allows multiple parties to collaboratively train a model without sharing sensitive medical data, ensuring data security and privacy. Transfer knowledge from multiple related datasets, reducing an ML model’s dependence on labeled training sets.
Data requirements Requires datasets from various hospitals in different locations to build a more robust model. Allows for the transfer of knowledge from one task to another.
Use cases Used to improve the quality and performance of anomaly detection models while maintaining user privacy. Used to improve the quality and precision of an anomaly detection model and reduce the computing resources required during the model training phase.
Performance Improves the scalability and efficiency of ML systems. Improves the accuracy and sensitivity of ML models in CD.
Privacy Protect privacy by allowing hospitals and medical patients not to send or share their sensitive information. Reduces the dependence of ML models on labeled training sets, thereby reducing the risk of privacy leaks.
Challenges Hardware limitations, communication and scheduling problems, and data distribution. Depends on a large set of labeled training data and determining which model is best suited for a specific healthcare use case.
references: Data homogeneity:

is very important in generating high quality and performant models. The similarity of data distributions between the source domain and the target domain allows increasing the efficiency of TL, especially in healthcare where the data is complex. These are types of data homogeneity:
Homogenous Data:
Homogeneous datasets can be beneficial for TL as they contain similar data from the same domain, which improved the efficiency and quality of the model. Chui et al.
chui2023facilitating

points out that homogeneous medical datasets may not be available or provide enough diversity to build robust models, which is why TL with heterogeneous datasets has become an emerging research initiative.
Heterogeneous data:

The presence of dissimilarity in data from different domains poses a challenge for TL when using heterogeneous datasets. This dissimilarity can lead to negative transfer, where the performance of the target model decreases after TL. Many researches have been conducted to solve this problem, such as Chui et al.
chui2023facilitating

proposed a generic incremental TL approach to address the challenges of TL with heterogeneous datasets. This approach can be useful for small datasets and for applications that may not have similar datasets.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4: Public Cancer Datasets
S4.T4.table:
URL Name Cancer Type Description # of Samples
D1 HAM10000 Skin A collection of multi-source dermatoscopic images of common pigmented skin lesions 10,015 images
D2 METABRIC Breast A dataset of genomic and clinical data from breast cancer patients Over 2,000 patients
D3 BCSC Breast A dataset of mammography and clinical data Over 2 million women
D4 CGGA Brain A dataset of genomic and clinical data from glioma patients Over 1,000 patients
D5 BraTS Brain A dataset of MRI scans of brain tumors for the purpose of developing algorithms for automated segmentation of brain tumors 1,000+ patients
D6 TCGA Colon A dataset of genomic, transcriptomic, and epigenomic data from colon cancer patients Over 400 patients
D7 GEO Colon A dataset of gene expression data from colon cancer patients Over 200 patients
D8 GDC Lung A dataset of genomic and clinical data from over 1,000 lung cancer patients Over 1,000 patients
D9 ICGC Lung A dataset of genomic and transcriptomic data from lung cancer patients Over 500 patients
D10 ISIC Skin A dataset of images of malignant and benign oncological diseases 2,357 images
references: This section provides an overview of the advantages and limitations of FL and TL for CD based on image analysis. An analysis for each technique is used for each learning type.

FL had several advantages for CD, including improving the diversity of the model and allowing personalized learning on client devices when using the FedAvg algorithm. FL also used fragmented medical data across sites while protecting privacy. As shown in Table

, using a 3D ResNet18 model trained with FedAvg. Bayesian modeling within FL handles recommendations for unseen groups and prevents collapsed representations. However, FL faces some limitations - the FedAvg algorithm can struggle to handle heterogeneous data distributions across clients. Small dataset sizes, as in an LSTM and Transformer FL model, limit performance. And convergence analysis remains challenging with algorithms like FedAvg.

TL also provides advantages for CD. TL improves accuracy and convergence rate compared to training a model from ground up, as demonstrated through a GoogLeNet model with Median Intensity Projections (MIP) for lung cancer. TL used features learned on large datasets by models like VGG16 and ResNet50 to improve performance on new tasks. ViTs like Swin Transformer and ViT capture global context from medical images to aid analysis. However, TL has some limitations. ViTs require large datasets for pretraining to be effective. Models like DenseNet121 generalize poorly to new patients or classes. And individual institutions often have limited datasets, as seen in a supervised contrastive learning model for embryo images. Table
highlights the main advantages and limitations of FL and TL.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Advantage and limitations of FL and TL for CD
S4.T5.table:
Ref Type Technique Advantage Limitation
liu2023federated FL 3D ResNet18 + FedAvg Utilizes fragmented medical data, protects privacy Effect of client number
fang2018novel TL GoogLeNet, MIPs Improves accuracy and convergence rate compared to training a CNN from ground up Develop a fast, accurate and stable DL system for lung cancer detection from CT scans
cai2021many FTL DGAN Augments limited data, protects privacy Impact of client number, malicious clients
li2023vision TL ViT Captures global context, outperforms CNN models Requires large datasets for pretraining
paya2022automatic TL SCL Improves embryo viability and quality classification Limited dataset from single clinic
wang2021survey TL K-means, spectral clustering Can produce good clustering results when instance size is small by transferring knowledge from source domain Most research focuses on classification and recognition, not clustering
das2021multi FL TDCD Communication efficient, exploits vertical and horizontal data partitions Analysis on non-IID data needed
ek2020evaluation FL FedAvg Improves model diversity and provides personalized learning on client devices Difficult to handle data distributions across clients
sharma2023deep TL VGG-16 Achieves high accuracy for pneumonia detection from chest X-rays Limited comparison to other best models
ikechukwu2021resnet TL ResNet-50, VGG-19 Improved performance over training from ground up Small dataset size
panthakkan2022concatenated TL Xception and ResNet50 Achieves high accuracy for skin cancer classification Image dataset is imbalanced
zidan2023swincup TL Swin Transformer and CNN Accurate segmentation, captures global context Dataset size
raval2023comprehensive TL AlexNet, VGGNet, Inception DenseNet achieved best performance for skin CD Limited dataset available for oral cancer, making detection difficult
dey2022screening TL DenseNet121 Accurate classification Single dataset
hanser2023federated FL Model-driven and data-driven FL Improves model performance and applicability domain Communication efficiency challenges
su2021hierarchical FL SCGDA Utilizes sample and feature diversity Convergence analysis needed
lee2022bayesian FL Bayesian modeling Handles recommendations for unseen groups. Better prevents collapsed representations Slower convergence compared to some existing models
kamei2023comparison FL LSTM, Transformer and FedAvg Decentralized approaches address data privacy and security issues Small dataset size
sun2022decentralized FL FedAvg blackuces communication bottlenecks, more robust to node failures and privacy attacks Convergence analysis is challenging
references: This section provides an overview of the advantages and limitations of FL and TL for CD based on image analysis. An analysis for each technique is used for each learning type.

FL had several advantages for CD, including improving the diversity of the model and allowing personalized learning on client devices when using the FedAvg algorithm. FL also used fragmented medical data across sites while protecting privacy. As shown in Table

, using a 3D ResNet18 model trained with FedAvg. Bayesian modeling within FL handles recommendations for unseen groups and prevents collapsed representations. However, FL faces some limitations - the FedAvg algorithm can struggle to handle heterogeneous data distributions across clients. Small dataset sizes, as in an LSTM and Transformer FL model, limit performance. And convergence analysis remains challenging with algorithms like FedAvg.

TL also provides advantages for CD. TL improves accuracy and convergence rate compared to training a model from ground up, as demonstrated through a GoogLeNet model with Median Intensity Projections (MIP) for lung cancer. TL used features learned on large datasets by models like VGG16 and ResNet50 to improve performance on new tasks. ViTs like Swin Transformer and ViT capture global context from medical images to aid analysis. However, TL has some limitations. ViTs require large datasets for pretraining to be effective. Models like DenseNet121 generalize poorly to new patients or classes. And individual institutions often have limited datasets, as seen in a supervised contrastive learning model for embryo images. Table
highlights the main advantages and limitations of FL and TL.
